The **Louisiana Purchase** ([French](/wiki/French_language "French language"):
_Vente de la Louisiane_ "Sale of Louisiana") was the acquisition of the
[Louisiana territory](/wiki/Louisiana_\(New_France\) "Louisiana \(New
France\)") (828,000 square miles or 2.14 million km²) by the [United
States](/wiki/United_States "United States") from
[France](/wiki/French_First_Republic "French First Republic") in 1803. The
U.S. paid fifty million [francs](/wiki/French_franc "French franc")
($11,250,000/€9,100,000) and a cancellation of debts worth eighteen million
francs ($3,750,000) for a total of sixty-eight million francs ($15 million,
equivalent to $300 million in 2016). The Louisiana territory included land
from fifteen present [U.S. states](/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state") and two
[Canadian provinces](/wiki/Canadian_provinces "Canadian provinces"). The
territory contained land that forms [Arkansas](/wiki/Arkansas "Arkansas"),
[Missouri](/wiki/Missouri "Missouri"), [Iowa](/wiki/Iowa "Iowa"),
[Oklahoma](/wiki/Oklahoma "Oklahoma"), [Kansas](/wiki/Kansas "Kansas"), and
[Nebraska](/wiki/Nebraska "Nebraska"); the portion of
[Minnesota](/wiki/Minnesota "Minnesota") west of the [Mississippi
River](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River"); a large portion of [North
Dakota](/wiki/North_Dakota "North Dakota"); a large portion of [South
Dakota](/wiki/South_Dakota "South Dakota"); the northeastern section of [New
Mexico](/wiki/New_Mexico "New Mexico"); the northern portion of
[Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas"); the area of [Montana](/wiki/Montana "Montana"),
[Wyoming](/wiki/Wyoming "Wyoming"), and [Colorado](/wiki/Colorado "Colorado")
east of the [Continental Divide](/wiki/Continental_Divide_of_the_Americas
"Continental Divide of the Americas"); [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana
"Louisiana") west of the Mississippi River (plus [New
Orleans](/wiki/%C3%8Ele_d%27Orl%C3%A9ans,_Louisiana "Île d'Orléans,
Louisiana")); and small portions of land within the present Canadian provinces
of [Alberta](/wiki/Alberta "Alberta") and [Saskatchewan](/wiki/Saskatchewan
"Saskatchewan"). Its non-native population was around 60,000 inhabitants, of
whom half were [African slaves](/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States "Slavery in
the United States").[1]

The [Kingdom of France](/wiki/Early_modern_France "Early modern France")
controlled the Louisiana territory from 1699 until it was
[ceded](/wiki/Treaty_of_Fontainebleau_\(1762\) "Treaty of Fontainebleau
\(1762\)") to [Spain](/wiki/Spanish_Empire "Spanish Empire") in 1762. In 1800,
[Napoleon](/wiki/Napoleon "Napoleon"), then the First Consul of the French
Republic, hoping to re-establish an empire in North America, regained
ownership of Louisiana. However, France's failure to put down the [revolt in
Saint-Domingue](/wiki/Haitian_Revolution "Haitian Revolution"), coupled with
the prospect of renewed warfare with the United Kingdom, prompted Napoleon to
sell Louisiana to the United States to fund his military. The Americans
originally sought to purchase only the port city of [New
Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans") and its adjacent coastal lands, but
quickly accepted the bargain. The Louisiana Purchase occurred during the term
of the third [President of the United
States](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United
States"), [Thomas Jefferson](/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas Jefferson").
Before the purchase was finalized, the decision faced [Federalist
Party](/wiki/Federalist_Party "Federalist Party") opposition; they argued that
it was unconstitutional to acquire any territory. Jefferson agreed that the
[U.S. Constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States
Constitution") did not contain explicit provisions for acquiring territory,
but he asserted that his constitutional power to negotiate treaties was
sufficient.

## Background

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Louisiana1804a.jpg/220px-
Louisiana1804a.jpg)](/wiki/File:Louisiana1804a.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Louisiana1804a.jpg "Enlarge")

1804 map of "[Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana_\(New_France\) "Louisiana \(New
France\)")", edged on the west by the [Rocky Mountains](/wiki/Rocky_Mountains
"Rocky Mountains")

Throughout the second half of the 18th century, Louisiana was a pawn on the
chessboard of European politics.[2] It was controlled by the French, who had a
few small settlements along the Mississippi and other main rivers. France
ceded the territory to Spain in the secret [Treaty of Fontainebleau
(1762)](/wiki/Treaty_of_Fontainebleau_\(1762\) "Treaty of Fontainebleau
\(1762\)"). Following French defeat in the [Seven Years'
War](/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War "Seven Years' War"), Spain gained control of
[the territory](/wiki/Louisiana_\(New_France\) "Louisiana \(New France\)")
west of the Mississippi and the British the territory to the east of the
river.[3]

Following the establishment of the United States, the Americans controlled the
area east of the Mississippi and north of New Orleans. The main issue for the
Americans was free transit of the Mississippi to the sea. As the lands were
being gradually settled by a few American migrants, many Americans, including
Jefferson, assumed that [the territory](/wiki/Louisiana_\(New_Spain\)
"Louisiana \(New Spain\)") would be acquired "piece by piece." The risk of
another power taking it from a weakened Spain made a "profound
reconsideration" of this policy necessary.[2] New Orleans was already
important for shipping agricultural goods to and from the areas of the United
States west of the [Appalachian Mountains](/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains
"Appalachian Mountains"). [Pinckney's Treaty](/wiki/Pinckney%27s_Treaty
"Pinckney's Treaty"), signed with Spain on October 27, 1795, gave American
merchants "right of deposit" in New Orleans, granting them use of the port to
store goods for export. Americans used this right to transport products such
as flour, tobacco, pork, bacon, lard, feathers, cider, butter, and cheese. The
treaty also recognized American rights to navigate the entire Mississippi,
which had become vital to the growing trade of the western territories.[3]

In 1798, Spain revoked the treaty allowing American use of New Orleans,
greatly upsetting Americans. In 1801, Spanish Governor Don [Juan Manuel de
Salcedo](/wiki/Juan_Manuel_de_Salcedo "Juan Manuel de Salcedo") took over from
the [Marquess of Casa
Calvo](/wiki/List_of_colonial_governors_of_Louisiana#Spanish_period "List of
colonial governors of Louisiana"), and restored the American right to deposit
goods. However, in 1800 Spain had ceded the Louisiana territory back to France
as part of [Napoleon](/wiki/Napoleon "Napoleon")'s secret [Third Treaty of San
Ildefonso](/wiki/Third_Treaty_of_San_Ildefonso "Third Treaty of San
Ildefonso").[4] The territory nominally remained under Spanish control, until
a transfer of power to [France](/wiki/French_First_Republic "French First
Republic") on 30 November 1803, just three weeks before the formal cession of
the territory to the United States on 20 December 1803.[5] A further ceremony
was held in [St. Louis](/wiki/St._Louis "St. Louis"), [Upper
Louisiana](/wiki/Illinois_Country "Illinois Country") regarding the [New
Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans") formalities. The 9–10 March 1804
event is remembered as [Three Flags Day](/wiki/Three_Flags_Day "Three Flags
Day").[6][7]

[James Monroe](/wiki/James_Monroe "James Monroe") and [Robert R.
Livingston](/wiki/Robert_R._Livingston_\(chancellor\) "Robert R. Livingston
\(chancellor\)") had traveled to [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris") to negotiate the
purchase of New Orleans in January 1803. Their instructions were to negotiate
or purchase control of New Orleans and its environs; they did not anticipate
the much larger acquisition which would follow.[8]

The Louisiana Purchase was by far the largest territorial gain in U.S.
history. Stretching from the [Mississippi River](/wiki/Mississippi_River
"Mississippi River") to the [Rocky Mountains](/wiki/Rocky_Mountains "Rocky
Mountains"), the purchase doubled the size of the [United
States](/wiki/United_States "United States"). Before 1803, Louisiana had been
under [Spanish control](/wiki/Louisiana_\(New_Spain\) "Louisiana \(New
Spain\)") for forty years. Although Spain aided the
[rebels](/wiki/Thirteen_Colonies "Thirteen Colonies") in the [American
Revolutionary War](/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War "American Revolutionary
War"), the Spanish didn't want the Americans to settle in their territory.[9]

Although the purchase was thought of by some as unjust and unconstitutional,
Jefferson determined that his constitutional power to negotiate treaties
allowed the purchase of what became fifteen states. In hindsight, the
Louisiana Purchase could be considered one of his greatest contributions to
the United States.[10] On April 18, 1802, Jefferson penned a letter to United
States Ambassador to France Robert Livingston. It was an intentional
exhortation to make this supposedly mild diplomat strongly warn the French of
their perilous course. The letter began:

> The cession of Louisiana and the Floridas by Spain to France works most
> sorely on the U.S. On this subject the Secretary of State has written to you
> fully. Yet I cannot forbear recurring to it personally, so deep is the
> impression it makes in my mind. It completely reverses all the political
> relations of the U.S. and will form a new epoch in our political course. Of
> all nations of any consideration France is the one which hitherto has
> offered the fewest points on which we could have any conflict of right, and
> the most points of a communion of interests. From these causes we have ever
> looked to her as our natural friend, as one with which we never could have
> an occasion of difference. Her growth therefore we viewed as our own, her
> misfortunes ours. There is on the globe one single spot, the possessor of
> which is our natural and habitual enemy. It is New Orleans, through which
> the produce of three-eighths of our territory must pass to market, and from
> its fertility it will ere long yield more than half of our whole produce and
> contain more than half our inhabitants. France placing herself in that door
> assumes to us the attitude of defiance. Spain might have retained it quietly
> for years. Her pacific dispositions, her feeble state, would induce her to
> increase our facilities there, so that her possession of the place would be
> hardly felt by us, and it would not perhaps be very long before some
> circumstance might arise which might make the cession of it to us the price
> of something of more worth to her. Not so can it ever be in the hands of
> France. The impetuosity of her temper, the energy and restlessness of her
> character, placed in a point of eternal friction with us...

Jefferson's letter went on with the same heat to a much quoted passage about
"the day that France takes possession of New Orleans." Not only did he say
that day would be a low point in France's history, for it would seal America's
marriage with the British fleet and nation, but he added, astonishingly, that
it would start a massive shipbuilding program.[11]

## Negotiation

While the transfer of the territory by Spain back to France in 1800 went
largely unnoticed, fear of an eventual French invasion spread nationwide when,
in 1801, Napoleon sent a military force to secure New Orleans. Southerners
feared that Napoleon would free all the slaves in Louisiana, which could
trigger slave uprisings elsewhere.[12] Though Jefferson urged moderation,
Federalists sought to use this against Jefferson and called for hostilities
against France. Undercutting them, Jefferson took up the banner and threatened
an alliance with the [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland "United Kingdom of
Great Britain and Ireland"), although relations were uneasy in that
direction.[12] In 1801 Jefferson supported France in its plan to take back
[Saint-Domingue](/wiki/Saint-Domingue "Saint-Domingue") (present-day
[Haiti](/wiki/Haiti "Haiti")), which was then under control of [Toussaint
Louverture](/wiki/Toussaint_Louverture "Toussaint Louverture") after a [slave
rebellion](/wiki/Slave_rebellion "Slave rebellion").

Jefferson sent Livingston to Paris in 1801[13] after discovering the transfer
of Louisiana from Spain to France under the [Third Treaty of San
Ildefonso](/wiki/Third_Treaty_of_San_Ildefonso "Third Treaty of San
Ildefonso"). Livingston was authorized to purchase New Orleans.

In January 1802, France sent [General Charles Leclerc](/wiki/Charles_Leclerc
"Charles Leclerc") to [Saint-Domingue](/wiki/Saint-Domingue "Saint-Domingue")
(present-day [Haiti](/wiki/Haiti "Haiti")) to [re-establish
slavery](/wiki/Saint-Domingue_expedition "Saint-Domingue expedition"), which
had been abolished by the [constitution of the French Republic of
1795](/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Year_III "Constitution of the Year III"), as
well as to reduce the rights of [free people of
color](/wiki/Free_people_of_color "Free people of color") and take back
control of the island from [Toussaint Louverture](/wiki/Toussaint_Louverture
"Toussaint Louverture"). Louverture had fended off invasions of St. Domingue
by the Spanish and British empires, but had also begun to consolidate power
for himself on the island. Before the Revolution, France had derived enormous
wealth from St. Domingue at the cost of the lives and freedom of the slaves.
Napoleon wanted its revenues and productivity for France restored. Alarmed
over the French actions and its intention to re-establish an empire in North
America, Jefferson declared neutrality in relation to the
[Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean "Caribbean"), refusing credit and other assistance
to the French, but allowing war contraband to get through to the rebels to
prevent France from regaining a foothold.[14]

In November 1803, France withdrew its 7,000 surviving troops from [Saint-
Domingue](/wiki/Saint-Domingue "Saint-Domingue") (more than two-thirds of its
troops died there) and gave up its ambitions in the [Western
Hemisphere](/wiki/Western_Hemisphere "Western Hemisphere").[15] In 1804 Haiti
declared its independence; but, fearing a slave revolt at home, Jefferson and
Congress refused to recognize the new republic, the second in the Western
Hemisphere, and imposed a trade [embargo](/wiki/Embargo "Embargo") against it.
This, together with later claims by France to reconquer Haiti, encouraged by
the United Kingdom, made it more difficult for Haiti to recover after ten
years of wars.[16]

In 1803, [Pierre Samuel du Pont de
Nemours](/wiki/Pierre_Samuel_du_Pont_de_Nemours "Pierre Samuel du Pont de
Nemours"), a French nobleman, began to help negotiate with France at the
request of Jefferson. Du Pont was living in the United States at the time and
had close ties to Jefferson as well as the prominent politicians in France. He
engaged in back-channel diplomacy with Napoleon on Jefferson's behalf during a
visit to France and originated the idea of the much larger Louisiana Purchase
as a way to defuse potential conflict between the United States and Napoleon
over North America.[17]

Jefferson disliked the idea of purchasing Louisiana from France, as that could
imply that France had a right to be in Louisiana. Jefferson had concerns that
a U.S. president did not have the constitutional authority to make such a
deal. He also thought that to do so would erode [states'
rights](/wiki/States%27_rights "States' rights") by increasing federal
executive power. On the other hand, he was aware of the potential threat that
France could be in that region and was prepared to go to war to prevent a
strong French presence there.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Throughout this time, Jefferson had up-to-date intelligence on Napoleon's
military activities and intentions in North America. Part of his evolving
strategy involved giving du Pont some information that was withheld from
Livingston. He also gave intentionally conflicting instructions to the
two.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] Desperate to avoid possible war with France, Jefferson sent [James
Monroe](/wiki/James_Monroe "James Monroe") to [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris") in
1803 to negotiate a settlement, with instructions to go to
[London](/wiki/London "London") to negotiate an alliance if the talks in Paris
failed. Spain procrastinated until late 1802 in executing the treaty to
transfer [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana_\(New_Spain\) "Louisiana \(New Spain\)")
to [France](/wiki/French_First_Republic "French First Republic"), which
allowed American hostility to build. Also, Spain's refusal to cede
[Florida](/wiki/Spanish_Florida "Spanish Florida") to France meant that
Louisiana would be indefensible. Monroe had been formally expelled from France
on his last diplomatic mission, and the choice to send him again conveyed a
sense of seriousness.

Napoleon needed peace with the United Kingdom to implement the [Treaty of San
Ildefonso](/wiki/Third_Treaty_of_San_Ildefonso "Third Treaty of San
Ildefonso") and take possession of Louisiana. Otherwise, Louisiana would be an
easy prey for the UK or even for the United States. But in early 1803,
continuing war between France and the UK seemed unavoidable. On March 11,
1803, Napoleon began preparing to invade the UK.

As Napoleon had failed to re-enslave the emancipated population of Haiti, he
abandoned his plans to rebuild France's [New World](/wiki/New_World "New
World") empire. Without sufficient revenues from [sugar](/wiki/Sugar_cane
"Sugar cane") colonies in the [Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean "Caribbean"),
Louisiana had little value to him. Spain had not yet completed the transfer of
Louisiana to France, and war between France and the UK was imminent. Out of
anger towards Spain and the unique opportunity to sell something that was
useless and not truly his yet, Napoleon decided to sell the entire
territory.[18]

Although the [foreign minister](/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_\(France\)
"Ministry of Foreign Affairs \(France\)")
[Talleyrand](/wiki/Charles_Maurice_de_Talleyrand "Charles Maurice de
Talleyrand") opposed the plan, on April 10, 1803, Napoleon told the Treasury
Minister [François de Barbé-Marbois](/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_de_Barb%C3%A9-Marbois
"François de Barbé-Marbois") that he was considering selling the entire
Louisiana Territory to the United States. On April 11, 1803, just days before
Monroe's arrival, Barbé-Marbois offered Livingston all of Louisiana for $15
million,[19] (equivalent to about $300 million in 2016 dollars,[20]) which
averages to less than three cents per acre (7 ¢/ha).[21][22]

The American representatives were prepared to pay up to $10 million for New
Orleans and its environs, but were dumbfounded when the vastly larger
territory was offered for $15 million. Jefferson had authorized Livingston
only to purchase New Orleans. However, Livingston was certain that the United
States would accept the offer.[23]

The Americans thought that Napoleon might withdraw the offer at any time,
preventing the United States from acquiring New Orleans, so they agreed and
signed the Louisiana Purchase Treaty on April 30, 1803. On July 4, 1803, the
treaty reached [Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.").
The Louisiana Territory was vast, stretching from the [Gulf of
Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico") in the south to [Rupert's
Land](/wiki/Rupert%27s_Land "Rupert's Land") in the north, and from the
Mississippi River in the east to the [Rocky Mountains](/wiki/Rocky_Mountains
"Rocky Mountains") in the west. Acquiring the territory would double the size
of the United States, at a sum of less than 3 cents per acre.

## Domestic opposition and constitutionality

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Louisiana_purchase_treaty.jpg/220px-
Louisiana_purchase_treaty.jpg)](/wiki/File:Louisiana_purchase_treaty.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Louisiana_purchase_treaty.jpg "Enlarge")

The original treaty of the Louisiana Purchase

[Henry Adams](/wiki/Henry_Adams "Henry Adams") and other historians have
argued that Jefferson acted hypocritically with the Louisiana Purchase, due to
his position as a [strict constructionist](/wiki/Strict_constructionism
"Strict constructionism") regarding the Constitution since he stretched the
intent of that document to justify his purchase.[24] This argument goes as
follows:

The American purchase of the Louisiana territory was not accomplished without
domestic opposition. Jefferson's philosophical consistency was in question
because of his strict interpretation of the Constitution. Many people believed
that he and others, including [James Madison](/wiki/James_Madison "James
Madison"), were doing something they surely would have argued against with
[Alexander Hamilton](/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton "Alexander Hamilton"). The
[Federalists](/wiki/Federalist_Party "Federalist Party") strongly opposed the
purchase, favoring close relations with Britain over closer ties to Napoleon,
and were concerned that the United States had paid a large sum of money just
to declare war on Spain.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Both Federalists and Jeffersonians were concerned over the purchase's
constitutionality. Many members of the House of Representatives opposed the
purchase. Majority Leader [John Randolph](/wiki/John_Randolph_of_Roanoke "John
Randolph of Roanoke") led the opposition. The House called for a vote to deny
the request for the purchase, but it failed by two votes, 59–57. The
Federalists even tried to prove the land belonged to Spain, not France, but
available records proved otherwise.[25]

The Federalists also feared that the power of the [Atlantic
seaboard](/wiki/Atlantic_seaboard "Atlantic seaboard") states would be
threatened by the new citizens in the West, whose political and economic
priorities were bound to conflict with those of the merchants and bankers of
[New England](/wiki/New_England "New England"). There was also concern that an
increase in the number of slave-holding states created out of the new
territory would exacerbate divisions between North and South as well. A group
of Northern Federalists led by Senator [Timothy
Pickering](/wiki/Timothy_Pickering "Timothy Pickering") of Massachusetts went
so far as to explore the idea of a separate northern confederacy.

Another concern was whether it was proper to grant citizenship to the French,
Spanish, and free black people living in New Orleans, as the treaty would
dictate. Critics in Congress worried whether these "foreigners", unacquainted
with democracy, could or should become citizens.[26]

Spain protested the transfer on two grounds: First, France had previously
promised in a note not to alienate Louisiana to a third party and second,
France had not fulfilled the [Third Treaty of San
Ildefonso](/wiki/Third_Treaty_of_San_Ildefonso "Third Treaty of San
Ildefonso") by having the King of [Etruria](/wiki/Etruria "Etruria")
recognized by all European powers. The French government replied that these
objections were baseless since the promise not to alienate Louisiana was not
in the treaty of San Ildefonso itself and therefore had no legal force, and
the Spanish government had ordered Louisiana to be transferred in October 1802
despite knowing for months that Britain had not recognized the King of Etruria
in the [Treaty of Amiens](/wiki/Treaty_of_Amiens "Treaty of Amiens").[27]

[](/wiki/File:Louisianatransfer_exposition1904_vc180.jpg "Enlarge")

_Transfer of Louisiana_ by Ford P. Kaiser for the [Louisiana Purchase

[Henry Adams](/wiki/Henry_Adams "Henry Adams") claimed "The sale of Louisiana
to the United States was trebly invalid; if it were French property, Bonaparte
could not constitutionally alienate it without the consent of the French
[Chambers](/wiki/S%C3%A9nat_conservateur "Sénat conservateur"); if it were
Spanish property, he could not alienate it at all; if Spain had a right of
reclamation, his sale was worthless."[28] The sale of course was not
"worthless"—the U.S. actually did take possession. Furthermore, the Spanish
prime minister had authorized the U.S. to negotiate with the French government
"the acquisition of territories which may suit their interests." Spain turned
the territory over to France in a ceremony in New Orleans on November 30, a
month before France turned it over to American officials.[29]

Other historians counter the above arguments regarding Jefferson's alleged
hypocrisy by asserting that countries change their borders in two ways: (1)
conquest, or (2) an agreement between nations, otherwise known as a treaty.
The Louisiana Purchase was the latter, a treaty. The Constitution specifically
grants the president the power to negotiate treaties (Art. II, Sec. 2), which
is just what Jefferson did.[30]

Jefferson's [Secretary of State](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State
"United States Secretary of State"), [James Madison](/wiki/James_Madison
"James Madison") (the "Father of the Constitution"), assured Jefferson that
the Louisiana Purchase was well within even the strictest interpretation of
the Constitution. Treasury Secretary [Albert Gallatin](/wiki/Albert_Gallatin
"Albert Gallatin") added that since the power to negotiate treaties was
specifically granted to the president, the only way extending the country's
territory by treaty could _not_ be a presidential power would be if it were
specifically excluded by the Constitution (which it was not). Jefferson, as a
strict constructionist, was right to be concerned about staying within the
bounds of the Constitution, but felt the power of these arguments and was
willing to "acquiesce with satisfaction" if the Congress approved the
treaty.[31]

The [Senate](/wiki/U.S._Senate "U.S. Senate") quickly ratified the treaty, and
the [House](/wiki/U.S._House_of_Representatives "U.S. House of
Representatives"), with equal alacrity, authorized the required funding, as
the Constitution specifies.[32][33]

The opposition of New England Federalists to the Louisiana Purchase was
primarily economic self-interest, not any legitimate concern over
constitutionality or whether France indeed owned Louisiana or was required to
sell it back to Spain should it desire to dispose of the territory. The
Northerners were not enthusiastic about Western farmers gaining another outlet
for their crops that did not require the use of New England ports. Also, many
Federalists were speculators in lands in upstate New York and New England and
were hoping to sell these lands to farmers, who might go west instead, if the
Louisiana Purchase went through. They also feared that this would lead to
Western states being formed, which would likely be Republican, and dilute the
political power of New England Federalists.[32][34]

When Spain later objected to the United States purchasing Louisiana from
France, Madison responded that America had first approached Spain about
purchasing the property, but had been told by Spain itself that America would
have to treat with France for the territory.[35]

## Treaty signing

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Louisiana_Purchase_1953_Issue-3c.jpg/220px-
Louisiana_Purchase_1953_Issue-3c.jpg)](/wiki/File:Louisiana_Purchase_1953_Issue-3c.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Louisiana_Purchase_1953_Issue-3c.jpg "Enlarge")

Issue of 1953, commemorating the 150th Anniversary of signing

The Louisiana Purchase Treaty was signed on 30 April by [Robert
Livingston](/wiki/Robert_R._Livingston_\(chancellor\) "Robert R. Livingston
\(chancellor\)"), [James Monroe](/wiki/James_Monroe "James Monroe"), and
[Barbé Marbois](/w/index.php?title=Barb%C3%A9_Marbois&action=edit&redlink=1
"Barbé Marbois \(page does not exist\)") in [Paris](/wiki/Paris,_France
"Paris, France"). Jefferson announced the treaty to the American people on
July 4. After the signing of the Louisiana Purchase agreement in 1803,
Livingston made this famous statement, "We have lived long, but this is the
noblest work of our whole lives... From this day the United States take their
place among the powers of the first rank."[36]

The [United States Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate")
advised and consented to ratification of the treaty with a vote of twenty-four
to seven on October 20. The Senators who voted against the treaty were:
[Simeon Olcott](/wiki/Simeon_Olcott "Simeon Olcott") and [William
Plumer](/wiki/William_Plumer "William Plumer") of New Hampshire, [William
Wells](/wiki/William_H._Wells "William H. Wells") and [Samuel
White](/wiki/Samuel_White_\(U.S._politician\) "Samuel White \(U.S.
politician\)") of Delaware, [James Hillhouse](/wiki/James_Hillhouse "James
Hillhouse") and [Uriah Tracy](/wiki/Uriah_Tracy "Uriah Tracy") of Connecticut,
and [Timothy Pickering](/wiki/Timothy_Pickering "Timothy Pickering") of
Massachusetts.

On the following day, October 21, 1803, the Senate authorized Jefferson to
take possession of the territory and establish a temporary military
government. In legislation enacted on October 31, Congress made temporary
provisions for local civil government to continue as it had under French and
Spanish rule and authorized the President to use military forces to maintain
order. Plans were also set forth for several missions to explore and chart the
territory, the most famous being the [Lewis and Clark
Expedition](/wiki/Lewis_and_Clark_Expedition "Lewis and Clark
Expedition").[37]

A timeline of legislation can be found at the Library of Congress: American
Memory:The Louisiana Purchase Legislative Timeline--1803-1804.[38]

## Formal transfers and initial organization

[](/wiki/File:Louisiana_Purchase_New_Orleans_Thure_de_Thulstrup.jpg "Enlarge")

Flag raising in the [Place d'Armes](/wiki/Jackson_Square_\(New_Orleans\)
"Jackson Square \(New Orleans\)") of [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New
Orleans"), marking the transfer of sovereignty over French Louisiana to the
United States, December 20, 1803, as depicted by [Thure de
Thulstrup](/wiki/Thure_de_Thulstrup "Thure de Thulstrup")

[France](/wiki/French_First_Republic "French First Republic") turned over [New
Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans"), the historic colonial
[capital](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city"), on December 20, 1803, at [the
Cabildo](/wiki/The_Cabildo "The Cabildo"), with a [flag-
raising](/wiki/Flag#Hoisting_the_flag "Flag") ceremony in the Plaza de Armas,
now [Jackson Square](/wiki/Jackson_Square_\(New_Orleans\) "Jackson Square
\(New Orleans\)"). Just three weeks earlier, on November 30, 1803, Spanish
officials had formally conveyed the colonial lands and their administration to
France.

On March 9 and 10, 1804, another ceremony, commemorated as [Three Flags
Day](/wiki/Three_Flags_Day "Three Flags Day"), was conducted in [St.
Louis](/wiki/St._Louis "St. Louis"), to transfer ownership of [Upper
Louisiana](/wiki/Illinois_Country "Illinois Country") from
[Spain](/wiki/New_Spain "New Spain") to the [French First
Republic](/wiki/French_First_Republic "French First Republic"), and then from
France to the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States"). From March
10 to September 30, 1804, Upper Louisiana was supervised as a military
district, under [Commandant](/wiki/Commandant "Commandant") [Amos
Stoddard](/wiki/Amos_Stoddard "Amos Stoddard").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Effective October 1, 1804, the purchased territory was
[organized](/wiki/Organized_territory "Organized territory") into the
[Territory of Orleans](/wiki/Territory_of_Orleans "Territory of Orleans")
(most of which would become the [state](/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state") of
Louisiana) and the [District of Louisiana](/wiki/District_of_Louisiana
"District of Louisiana"), which was temporarily under control of the governor
and judicial system of the [Indiana Territory](/wiki/Indiana_Territory
"Indiana Territory"). The following year, the District of Louisiana was
renamed the [Territory of Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana_Territory "Louisiana
Territory"), aka Louisiana Territory (1805–1812).[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

New Orleans was the administrative capital of the Orleans Territory, and St.
Louis was the capital of the Louisiana Territory.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Boundaries

A dispute soon arose between Spain and the United States regarding the extent
of Louisiana. The territory's boundaries had not been defined in the 1762
[Treaty of Fontainebleau](/wiki/Treaty_of_Fontainebleau_\(1762\) "Treaty of
Fontainebleau \(1762\)") that ceded it from France to Spain, nor in the 1801
Third Treaty of San Ildefonso ceding it back to France, nor the 1803 Louisiana
Purchase agreement ceding it to the United States.[39]

The United States claimed Louisiana included the entire western portion of the
Mississippi River drainage basin to the crest of the Rocky Mountains and land
extending southeast to the [Rio Grande](/wiki/Rio_Grande "Rio Grande") and
[West Florida](/wiki/West_Florida "West Florida").[40] Spain insisted that
Louisiana comprised no more than the western bank of the Mississippi River and
the cities of New Orleans and St. Louis.[41] The dispute was ultimately
resolved by the [Adams–Onís Treaty](/wiki/Adams%E2%80%93On%C3%ADs_Treaty
"Adams–Onís Treaty") of 1819, with the United States gaining most of what it
had claimed in the west.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/UnitedStatesExpansion.png/350px-
UnitedStatesExpansion.png)](/wiki/File:UnitedStatesExpansion.png)

[](/wiki/File:UnitedStatesExpansion.png "Enlarge")

The Purchase was one of several territorial additions to the U.S.

The relatively narrow [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana_\(New_Spain\) "Louisiana
\(New Spain\)") of [New Spain](/wiki/New_Spain "New Spain") had been a special
province under the jurisdiction of the [Captaincy General of
Cuba](/wiki/Captaincy_General_of_Cuba "Captaincy General of Cuba") while the
vast region to the west was in 1803 still considered part of the Commandancy
General of the [Provincias Internas](/wiki/Provincias_Internas "Provincias
Internas"). Louisiana had never been considered one of New Spain's internal
provinces.[42]

If the territory included all the tributaries of the Mississippi on its
western bank, the northern reaches of the Purchase extended into the equally
ill-defined British possession—[Rupert's Land](/wiki/Rupert%27s_Land "Rupert's
Land") of [British North America](/wiki/British_North_America "British North
America"), now part of Canada. The Purchase originally extended just beyond
the [50th parallel](/wiki/50th_parallel_north "50th parallel north"). However,
the territory north of the [49th parallel](/wiki/49th_parallel_north "49th
parallel north") (including the [Milk
River](/wiki/Milk_River_\(Alberta%E2%80%93Montana\) "Milk River
\(Alberta–Montana\)") and [Poplar
River](/wiki/Poplar_River_\(Montana%E2%80%93Saskatchewan\) "Poplar River
\(Montana–Saskatchewan\)") watersheds) was ceded to the UK in exchange for
parts of the [Red River Basin](/wiki/Red_River_Basin "Red River Basin") south
of [49th parallel](/wiki/49th_parallel_north "49th parallel north") in the
[Anglo-American Convention of 1818](/wiki/Treaty_of_1818 "Treaty of
1818").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

The eastern boundary of the Louisiana purchase was the Mississippi River, from
its source to the [31st parallel](/wiki/31st_parallel_north "31st parallel
north"), though [the source of the Mississippi](/wiki/Lake_Itasca "Lake
Itasca") was, at the time, unknown. The eastern boundary below the 31st
parallel was unclear. The U.S. claimed the land as far as the [Perdido
River](/wiki/Perdido_River "Perdido River"), and Spain claimed that the border
of its Florida Colony remained the [Mississippi River](/wiki/Mississippi_River
"Mississippi River"). In early 1804, Congress passed the Mobile Act, which
recognized [West Florida](/wiki/West_Florida "West Florida") as part of the
United States. The Adams–Onís Treaty with Spain (1819) resolved the issue upon
ratification in 1821. Today, the 31st parallel is the northern boundary of the
western half of the [Florida Panhandle](/wiki/Florida_Panhandle "Florida
Panhandle"), and the Perdido is the western boundary of Florida.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Because the western boundary was contested at the time of the Purchase,
President Jefferson immediately began to organize three missions to explore
and map the new territory. All three started from the Mississippi River. The
[Lewis and Clark Expedition](/wiki/Lewis_and_Clark_Expedition "Lewis and Clark
Expedition") (1804) traveled up the [Missouri River](/wiki/Missouri_River
"Missouri River"); the [Red River Expedition
(1806)](/wiki/Red_River_Expedition_\(1806\) "Red River Expedition \(1806\)")
explored the Red River basin; the [Pike Expedition](/wiki/Pike_Expedition
"Pike Expedition") (1806) also started up the Missouri, but turned south to
explore the [Arkansas River](/wiki/Arkansas_River "Arkansas River") watershed.
The maps and journals of the explorers helped to define the boundaries during
the negotiations leading to the Adams–Onís Treaty, which set the western
boundary as follows: north up the [Sabine
River](/wiki/Sabine_River_\(Texas%E2%80%93Louisiana\) "Sabine River
\(Texas–Louisiana\)") from the [Gulf of Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of
Mexico") to its intersection with the [32nd
parallel](/wiki/32nd_parallel_north "32nd parallel north"), due north to the
[Red River](/wiki/Red_River_of_the_South "Red River of the South"), up the Red
River to the [100th meridian](/wiki/100th_meridian_west "100th meridian
west"), north to the [Arkansas River](/wiki/Arkansas_River "Arkansas River"),
up the Arkansas River to its headwaters, due north to the [42nd
parallel](/wiki/42nd_parallel_north "42nd parallel north") and due west to its
previous boundary.

## Slavery

See also: [History of slavery in
Louisiana](/wiki/History_of_slavery_in_Louisiana "History of slavery in
Louisiana"), [History of slavery in
Missouri](/wiki/History_of_slavery_in_Missouri "History of slavery in
Missouri"), and [Slavery in the United
States](/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States "Slavery in the United States")

Governing the Louisiana Territory was more difficult than acquiring it. Its
European peoples, of ethnic French, Spanish and Mexican descent, were largely
[Catholic](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church"); in addition, there was a
large population of [enslaved Africans](/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States
"Slavery in the United States") made up of a high proportion of recent
arrivals, as [Spain](/wiki/Louisiana_\(New_Spain\) "Louisiana \(New Spain\)")
had continued the international [slave trade](/wiki/Slave_trade "Slave
trade"). This was particularly true in the area of the present-day state of
Louisiana, which also contained a large number of [free people of
color](/wiki/Free_people_of_color "Free people of color"). Both present-day
Arkansas and Missouri already had some [slaveholders](/wiki/Slaveholder
"Slaveholder") in the early 19th century.

During this period, south Louisiana received an influx of French-speaking
refugee [planters](/wiki/Planter_\(American_South\) "Planter \(American
South\)"), who were permitted to bring their slaves with them, and other
refugees fleeing the large [slave revolt](/wiki/Haitian_Revolution "Haitian
Revolution") in [Saint-Domingue](/wiki/Saint-Domingue "Saint-Domingue"),
today's [Haiti](/wiki/Haiti "Haiti"). Many Southern slaveholders feared that
acquisition of the new territory might inspire American-held slaves to follow
the example of those in Saint-Domingue and revolt. They wanted the US
government to establish laws allowing slavery in the newly acquired territory
so they could be supported in taking their slaves there to undertake new
agricultural enterprises, as well as to reduce the threat of future [slave
rebellions](/wiki/Slave_rebellion "Slave rebellion").[43]

The Louisiana Territory was broken into smaller portions for administration,
and the territories passed slavery laws similar to those in the southern
states but incorporating provisions from the preceding French and Spanish rule
(for instance, Spain had prohibited slavery of Native Americans in 1769, but
some slaves of mixed [African](/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_Africa "Ethnic groups of
Africa")-[Native American](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native
Americans in the United States") descent were still being held in [St.
Louis](/wiki/St._Louis "St. Louis") in [Upper
Louisiana](/wiki/Illinois_Country "Illinois Country") when the U.S. took
over).[44] In a [freedom suit](/wiki/Freedom_suit "Freedom suit") that went
from Missouri to the [US Supreme Court](/wiki/US_Supreme_Court "US Supreme
Court"), slavery of Native Americans was finally ended in 1836.[44] The
institutionalization of slavery under U.S. law in the Louisiana Territory
contributed to the [American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American
Civil War") a half century later.[43] As states organized within the
territory, the status of slavery in each state became a matter of contention
in Congress, as southern states wanted slavery extended to the west, and
northern states just as strongly opposed new states being admitted as "[slave
states](/wiki/Free_and_slave_states "Free and slave states")."

The [Missouri Compromise](/wiki/Missouri_Compromise "Missouri Compromise") of
1820 was a temporary solution.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Asserting U.S. possession

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Fort_Madison_1810.jpg/170px-
Fort_Madison_1810.jpg)](/wiki/File:Fort_Madison_1810.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Fort_Madison_1810.jpg "Enlarge")

Plan of [Fort Madison](/wiki/Fort_Madison "Fort Madison"), built in 1808 to
establish U.S. control over the northern part of the Louisiana Purchase, drawn
1810

After the early explorations, the U.S. government sought to establish control
of the region, since trade along the Mississippi and Missouri rivers was still
dominated by British and French traders from Canada and allied
[Indians](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native Americans in the
United States"), especially the [Sauk](/wiki/Sauk_people "Sauk people") and
[Fox](/wiki/Fox_\(tribe\) "Fox \(tribe\)"). The U.S. adapted the former
Spanish facility at [Fort Bellefontaine](/wiki/Fort_Bellefontaine "Fort
Bellefontaine") as a fur trading post near St. Louis in 1804 for business with
the Sauk and Fox.[45] In 1808 two military forts with trading factories were
built, [Fort Osage](/wiki/Fort_Osage "Fort Osage") along the [Missouri
River](/wiki/Missouri_River "Missouri River") in western present-day Missouri
and [Fort Madison](/wiki/Fort_Madison "Fort Madison") along the [Upper
Mississippi River](/wiki/Upper_Mississippi_River "Upper Mississippi River") in
eastern present-day Iowa.[46] With tensions increasing with Great Britain, in
1809 Fort Bellefontaine was converted to a U.S. military fort, and was used
for that purpose until 1826.

During the [War of 1812](/wiki/War_of_1812 "War of 1812"), Great Britain and
allied Indians defeated U.S. forces in the Upper Mississippi; the U.S.
abandoned Forts Osage and Madison, as well as several other U.S. forts built
during the war, including [Fort Johnson](/wiki/Fort_Johnson "Fort Johnson")
and [Fort Shelby](/wiki/Fort_Shelby_\(Wisconsin\) "Fort Shelby
\(Wisconsin\)"). After U.S. ownership of the region was confirmed in the
[Treaty of Ghent](/wiki/Treaty_of_Ghent "Treaty of Ghent") (1814), the U.S.
built or expanded forts along the Mississippi and Missouri rivers, including
adding to Fort Bellefontaine, and constructing [Fort
Armstrong](/wiki/Fort_Armstrong,_Illinois "Fort Armstrong, Illinois") (1816)
and [Fort Edwards](/wiki/Warsaw,_Illinois "Warsaw, Illinois") (1816) in
Illinois, [Fort Crawford](/wiki/Fort_Crawford "Fort Crawford") (1816) in
[Prairie du Chien](/wiki/Prairie_du_Chien "Prairie du Chien") Wisconsin, [Fort
Snelling](/wiki/Fort_Snelling "Fort Snelling") (1819) in Minnesota, and [Fort
Atkinson](/wiki/Fort_Atkinson_\(Nebraska\) "Fort Atkinson \(Nebraska\)")
(1819) in Nebraska.[46]

## Financing

The American government used $3 million in gold as a down payment, and issued
bonds for the balance to pay France for the purchase. Earlier that year,
[Francis Baring and Company](/wiki/Barings_Bank "Barings Bank") of London had
become the U.S. government's official banking agent in London. Because of this
favored position, the U.S. asked the Baring firm to handle the transaction.
Francis Baring's son [Alexander](/wiki/Alexander_Baring,_1st_Baron_Ashburton
"Alexander Baring, 1st Baron Ashburton") was in Paris at the time and helped
in the negotiations.[47] Another Baring advantage was a close relationship
with [Hope and Company](/wiki/Hope_%26_Co. "Hope & Co.") of Amsterdam. The two
banking houses worked together to facilitate and underwrite the Purchase.

Because Napoleon wanted to receive his money as quickly as possible, the two
firms received the American bonds and shipped the gold to France.[47] Napoleon
used the money to finance his [planned invasion of
England](/wiki/Napoleon%27s_planned_invasion_of_the_United_Kingdom "Napoleon's
planned invasion of the United Kingdom"), which never took place.[48]
